newsitem.title: UK: LME prices stable in pre-market, spreads hold key.
newsitem.headline: LME prices stable in pre-market, spreads hold key.

text.p: Base metals prices hovered near previous closing levels in a subdued pre-market on Thursday after London Metal Exchange (LME) stocks offered no surprises.
But traders said they were closely watching nearby spreads on copper, aluminium and zinc for direction on these markets.
Aluminium's solid gains on Wednesday sparked by speculators were expected to extend to $1,650 and then $1,670, traders said.
In the pre-market light speculative short covering was countered by profit-taking. Three months prices were last at $1,646/1,648 per tonne, versus $1,642 at the kerb close.
"The 1,650 level has been hard to get through which encouraged some profit-taking. The market has paused but the spread is underpinning the rally," a trader said.
He was referring to growing tightness in nearby months, exacerbated by steadily declining stocks.
The cash/threes contango contracted to $8/$5 on Thursday morning, compared to around $20 earlier in the week.
Zinc, the star of the complex which marched to fresh seven-year highs on Wednesday, is also seen firmer.
But zinc is very oversold, with the 14-day RSI above the 80 level, and the market may need to consolidate gains around current levels before proceeding higher, traders said.
On the upside $1,580 and then $1,600 were targets.
Market sentiment was decidedly more bearish for copper, due to steady LME stock rises and a contracting backwardation.
For the time being, however, it was was firmer at $2,282/$2,285 per tonne against Wednesday's close of $2,273.
Cash to threes backwardation was at $60/$65, little changed from Wednesday afternoon but down sharply from last week's peak of $270 as recent tightness unwound.
LME stocks rose by 3,950 tonnes, bringing the total reported inventories to 204,900 tonnes.
"People are looking for copper to go lower, but it doesn't look ready to break down just yet," a trader said.

In the other metals, nickel probed the $6,800 level early on, following overnight news of a breakdown in contract talks between nickel producer Falconbridge Ltd and a union representing 1,400 workers at its Sudbury, Onatrio operations.
The current contract expires at the end of the month.
But prices edged back down to $6,780/$6,790 little changed from the kerb close of $6,780.
Tin edged up by $10 to $5,380 while lead was quoted at $648/$650 versus $650.
Alloy was indicated unchanged at $1,465/$,1,470.
--Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
